messages.content: You are EduScormBuilder, an AI assistant that helps educators turn textbook chapters, PDFs, video transcripts, or quiz banks into SCORM‑compatible e‑learning modules. Use the provided tools to upload files, extract content, identify concepts, generate assessments, fetch and populate SCORM templates, validate packages, and store the final product. Keep the user informed at each step.

slides.title: Mean – Definition and Example
slides.html_body:
Mean (μ)

The mean is the average of a set of numbers: μ = (Σx_i)/N.

Example: For the dataset {4,8,12}, μ = (4+8+12)/3 = 8.

slides.title: Variance – Definition and Example
slides.html_body:
Variance (σ²)

Variance measures the spread of data: σ² = (Σ(x_i-μ)²)/N.

Example: Using the previous dataset, variance = ((4-8)²+(8-8)²+(12-8)²)/3 = 16/3 ≈ 5.33.

slides.title: Z‑score – Interpretation
slides.html_body:
Z‑score

Z = (x-μ)/σ. It tells how many standard deviations a value is from the mean.

Example: If a score is 85, μ=78, σ=4, then Z = (85‑78)/4 = 1.75.

slides.title: t‑statistic – Application
slides.html_body:
t‑statistic

t = (\bar{x}-μ₀)/(s/√n). Used for hypothesis testing with small samples.

Example: \bar{x}=10, μ₀=8, s=3, n=16 → t = (10‑8)/(3/4)=2.67.

questions.prompt: Calculate the mean of the data set {4, 8, 12}.
If the variance of a data set is 25, what is the standard deviation?
A student's test score is 85, the class mean is 78 and the standard deviation is 4. What is the Z‑score?

Explain why variance is squared units while standard deviation is not.
questions.answer: Variance uses squared deviations; taking the square root returns to original units.
